content:
I doubt the issue is Thunderbird. I am using Gmail accounts without issue in the 112 version.

A timeout error sounds like a firewall or an anti virus issue. The firewall is blocking Thunderbird or the antivirus is trying to scan mail on the account and generally crashing the connection so it times out.

This idea is reinforced by the fact outlook and windows mail also fail to play nicely.

content:
I suggest you have a looking the certificate manager and identify the certificate you added the exception for. That might offer some clue as the the source of the issue.

Also delete any saved passwords for the account in the password manager. Not having a password may allow the actual error to bubble up to where it can be seen. But I would guess, like you, that the certificate is no longer valid.

Finally what are the settings being used for the outgoing server?

A DNS search for the domain you mention https://intodns.com/edcmeals.com shows the mail exchanger is registered as mail.edcmeals.com. While this may not be the mail submission server, it usually is. A test of the SSL/TLS for the domain using the default encrypted port of 465 got me a result that the mail server is vulnerable to about every serious hack in the last 5 years. It got a F rating https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/mail.edcmeals.com/2pHva0TL/

I am guessing the main issue of is the size of the key at 1025bits. 2048 has been a basic requirement for the majority of the last 10 years. The logjam vulnerability having come to light in 2015.

Personally I feel the encrypted connection is next to useless in this case. I would suggest you look as using a non encrypted connection to the server if you can do nothing about the general standard of the encryption used.

I look at the whois registry information for the domain https://who.is/whois/edcmeals.com and using the diagnostics there and a traceRT, it looks like the server may be an on premises device, hosted on the old road runner network. If that is the case I strongly suggest some update to the server configuration. It is way out of date with regards to security, at a time of heightened international activity with regard to nation sponsored hacking.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: You should be able to create a local folder and copy messages to the local folder and then delete from server.
creator: davidsk

content:
danbollinger said
You misread my post are comment.

Well I have read it all and to be blunt, I have no idea what the discussion is about. You have changed the port from from 465 to 587 and now I assume you get some sort of sending error. What is it? Clearly it has nothing to do with TLS. Without knowing what the actual error is, offering anything but platitudes is not really an option.

What I do know about the bargain basement solutions offered by network solutions is they fail entirely to offer a valid SSL certificate for the server you are asked to connect to and a manual exception has to be created for each and every host and port used. You I guess have an exception recorder for the old port but not the new. I also have seen a couple of topics suggesting a bug in the request for a certificate not occurring if the password is saved. So I suggest you go to the saved passwords in Thunderbird and delete the saved password for that outgoing account. That should allow the prompt to appear (if my reading between the lines is any good.)
creator: MattAuSupport

content: You misread my post are comment.

The Thunderbird email client has supported TLS 1.2 by default since Tb 78.0

changed TLS 1.0 and 1.1 disabled

content: Does 465 still work? I suggest experimenting a bit. Try 465 and see if that works. If not, change the authentication (e.g., if it was ssl/tls, try starttls). ALso, try changing authentication with 587. It is not unusual for email hosts to give incomplete instructions. Let us know.
